name: places/ChIJl1fi6-dYwokR_-h1dn01q5I
adrFormatAddress: 1114 1st Ave., New York, NY 10065, USA

editorialSummary.text: Long-standing nonprofit chain with a range of pre-owned clothing, housewares & more.

originalText.text:
The staff in this Goodwill is so rude. The store closes at 7 pm and, because I work, I went to drop off clothes for donations at 6:45 pm (I showed up 15 minutes before closing, which is reasonable). One male employee was smoking outside and one female employee was guarding the door from the inside. As I approached to clearly drop off donations (that fit in 1 bag), the male complained that they close at 7 and that my visit was basically too close to closing time, so I said I didn’t know (meaning I didn’t know you couldn’t just drop off a bag of donations within 15 minutes of closing time, it’s not like I need to spend any time there, they can just leave it inside for the night and deal with it the next day). The male told me to leave it inside just at the entrance, and the female said in a very mean tone “everybody says they didn’t know”, so I said “excuse me for giving you free clothes” and she responded immediately “I don’t care about your clothes”. I told her to go **** herself, took my bag and left. I dropped it off at Housing Works 5 minutes away, they close at the same time and they gladly took the bag without hesitation, even offered a receipt, and were super nice, and never made me feel like this was any inconvenience.
The people at this Goodwill are so condescending and clearly don’t have any sense of professionalism.
I don’t see why they can’t let someone drop off their donation and leave it sit in the store overnight, I don’t see how this represents an obstacle in them going home on time.

originalText.text:
Today I went to Goodwill to donate a small bag of kitchen supplies. Upon arrival I walked to the fairly empty donation area and was loudly told from an employee that they were not accepting any more donations and that I should try another location.

I said "ok" and stood for a moment to think about what to do (try the other location, go straight home, etc.). He proceeded to yell that they were not accepting donations. I told him I was leaving, and that there was no reason to yell. He told me I wasn't listening and continued to yell at me.

I left the store and then re-entered and told him I'd like to speak  to his manager. He said his manager would say the same thing, that they were not accepting donations. I said it's not about the donations - I do not deserve to be spoken to that way. He then proceeded to ignore me. I asked for his name, nothing. I stood by the door and waited for his manager. He continued to ignore me.

His manager eventually came 15 minutes later and apologized. Again, this is not about the donations, but being yelled and berated by someone who is clearly taking their frustration out at you. It's unpleasant and uncalled for.

originalText.text:
This used to be a good Goodwill store but now its like...meh... The workers have no pride in their store, its was dirty and unkempt.  The donations where piled into a heap right in the front of the store.  They had shirts for $15.99.  Come on now, these are items that are donated or thrown away! The security is ridiculous, the last time I was here I saw a lady shoplifting! I don't think I will be returning any time soon.
Goodwill is located on 1114 1st Ave.  New York City.  Opens at 10am

originalText.text:
tldr: unwritten (and questionably real) rules around donation times, will be donating elsewhere.

We tried to donate clothes and were told by evening staff that they stop accepting donations at 6pm (1 hour before closing). I cannot find this policy anywhere on Goodwill's website or anywhere related to the location. From the outside, the bins were clearly not full. A store employee said that I should have called and then I would have known.

If this is an official policy, put it explicitly on the store and where people look. It sounds like it was something informal for this particular group of staff.

I'll be avoiding this location and going to ones without unwritten rules you have to call to know about. We had taken a cab and dropped off en route to another event, so left the items where we usually leave our donations - I certainly hope the staff didn't just throw them out, as other reviewers seem to have noted.

originalText.text: I was very impressed with the men's clothing here.  The men's section was still smaller than the woman's,  but had a better selection than many other thrift sites I've been to.  Everything was clean and organized and easy to search.  The home goods and other sections were really lacking,  but I was impressed by the quality of the clothing there (maybe that's just because I found a suit that fit me perfectly! )
